_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Storage Tanks, Pump, Hoses, Popoffs, Excess Flow Devices, Plumbing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UAP Distribution, Inc.
East 2nd Street (office located at 206 Washington)
Tipton, KS 67485
(785) 373-4445 OR Downs Office (785) 454-3305

Updated to provide revised corporate information and to include new required RMP information.  UAP Distribution, Inc. is the owner of this facility, having purchased it from Boettcher Enterprises, Inc. and Tipton Fertilizer and Chemical

For further information contact:  Dale Buxman, ERS Area Manager, 5701 Eureka Bend, McKinney, TX 75070 (972) 489-3154, or; Norwood Naasz, Location Manager, UAP Distribution, Inc. 415 Commercial, Downs, KS 64737 (785) 454-3305
Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of UAP Distribution, Inc.,  are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire company, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  Facility Information - UAP Distribution, Inc., 2nd Street, Tipton, Kansas  67485 (785) 373-4445.  The ammonia storage tank is located approximately 1/4 mile North on 2nd Street on the East side of the road.  Ammonia nurse trailers are occasionally stored at the facility office, and a separate RMP has been submitted for this storage area.

 The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.

 Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application.

 The maximum quantity stored would be potentially 265,000 pounds, composed of our two storage tanks, one of 11,000 gallon capacity and one of 12,000 gallon capacity,  holding a combined 102,000 pounds and on a seasonal basis, a maximum of 22, 1000 gallon nurse trailers and 5, 1500 gallon nurse trailers, holding 164,000 pounds.

Operating procedures for an emergency situation, unloading at a storage facility, and loading of ammonia nurse trailers

have been updated as of 03/08/2007.

3.  The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

a.  The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tanks, released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 110,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank(s)  at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 2.22 miles.

b.  The alternative release scenario based on the five-year accident history (or the most likely potential incident is a release from a ruptured hose.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 0.47 miles.

4.  The accidental release prevention program.

The facility has implemented most of the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29  CFR 1910.111, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  The governing regulations are put forth by the Kansas Department of Agriculture and the facility is inspected on a regular basis by company personnel, inspectors from the Kansas Department of Agriculture, and representatives of the Company's insurance carrier.  Important differences between ANSI standards and KDA regulations involve color coding of valves, installation of a bulkhead at the truck unloading point, and remote shut-offs for the storage tank(s).  The Company has adopted a plan to bring all facilities and equipment into compliance with the full ANSI standards by the end of 2004.

5.  The Five-year Accident History 

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor  to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacua

tions, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
   
6.  The emergency response program.

 The facility has:

a.  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR1910.38; a copy of the plan has been provided to local authorities.

b.  provided a copy of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) to local authorities.

c.  provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7.  Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  At least annually,  evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional, specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.  Training is on-going and accomplished through a combination of in-company, seminars, use of videos, and site-specific analysis.
